title: Best gravel bike wheels 2025
content:

Best gravel bike wheels 2025

The best gravel bike wheels are purpose-designed for wider gravel bike tyres and the rough conditions gravel riders experience.

They’re usually a little stronger and sometimes a little wider than the best road bike wheels, although the latter are catching up in terms of internal rim width. As with road bike wheels, aerodynamics are increasingly important for gravel bike wheels, although rim depths are usually shallower. The aerodynamics are usually tuned for lower riding speeds too.

The best gravel bike wheels are invariably tubeless-ready and designed for disc brakes. They’ll usually have a freehub with fast engagement too, so that there’s no lag in power transfer once you start to pedal. Many gravel bike wheelsets are equally at home on the road and there’s a growing sub-category of all-road wheels designed to cover both road and gravel use.

We’ve reviewed a fair few gravel bike wheelsets at Cyclist. Below are our picks of the best gravel bike wheels to enhance the performance of even the best gravel bikes and further down we have a buyer’s guide to what to look for in gravel wheels.

Our pick of the best gravel bike wheels

  1. Bontrager Aeolus Pro 37V – read our full review
  2. Cadex AR 35 Disc
  3. Campagnolo Levante
  4. DT Swiss GR 1600 Spline Dyn
  5. DT Swiss GRC Dicut
  6. Enve AG25 / AG28
  7. Fulcrum Sharq – read our full review
  8. Hunt 35 Carbon Gravel – read our full review
  9. Parcours FKT
  10. Zipp 303 XPLR SW – read our full review

Why trust Cyclist‘s advice?

We’ve reviewed a wide range of gravel bikes, both gravel race bikes and gravel adventure bikes here at Cyclist, as well as some of the best gravel bike wheels, gravel tyres and all the assorted paraphernalia that goes with gravel riding. We’ve ridden gravel bikes from the low priced to the very expensive, along with the wheels that go with them.

That means that we know our gravel wheels and which to recommend. We choose the most newsworthy equipment and aren’t paid for our reviews, so you can trust Cyclist to offer an unbiased opinion.

The best gravel bike wheels 2025

Bontrager Aeolus Pro 37V 

£1,799.98 | View offer

  • 25mm internal width supports gravel tyres well
  • FusionFiber rims help reduce vibration and are fully recyclable

Bontrager bills the Aeolus Pro 37V as a wheelset that can do double duty on road and on gravel, with its 25mm internal width supporting a wide range of tyre widths from 28mm up. The 1,470g wheelset weight is competitive and there’s a freehub with 108 points of engagement for rapid take-up.

Trek builds the rims using FusionFiber, which is claimed to be less brittle and the composition of which allows recycling at end of life, unlike conventional epoxy resins. We found it led to a smooth ride, while the rims are laterally stiff and support gravel tyres well.

  • Buy now from Trek Bikes (£1,799.98)

Cadex AR 35 Disc

£2,499.98 | View offer

  • 35mm depth, 25mm internal width and 1,270g claimed weight
  • 60 tooth ratchet freehub for fast engagement

Cadex’s all-road/gravel wheelset has a low claimed 1,270g weight and 25mm internal width rim with a hookless bead, laced to its hubs with aero carbon spokes. Cadex claims high lateral stiffness and a fast pick-up from its R-Drive 60 tooth ratchet freehub. It sells 40mm width gravel tyres to go along with its wheels, with two options depending on how much grip you need.

Cadex employs its Dynamic Balanced Lacing in the wheels, as also used in its road wheels. This has slightly different tensions between forward facing and rearward facing spokes, which Cadex says evens out once you start to ride. The 21 spokes in the front wheel and the 24 in the rear are laced 2:1.

  • Read more details on the Cadex AR 35 wheels

Campagnolo Levante

£1,349.99 | View offer

  • Mid-depth with 25mm wide sealed rim bed
  • Designed for durability and ease of servicing

The Campagnolo Levante wheelset offers a match for the brand’s Ekar gravel groupset. Campagnolo says it’s designed for low weight, 1,485g, and handling, as well as durability and serviceability. While many gravel wheel rims have gone hookless, the Levante has ‘mini-hooks’. Its 25mm internal width, 30mm deep rim is also airtight without needing to be taped.

Campagnolo’s production method means no need to lacquer the wheels and the decals are laser etched, so there should be less chance of the appearance being marred with use. The Levante retains the cup and cone bearings favoured by Campagnolo and there are external spoke nipples, both of which should aid servicing. You can choose Shimano HD or SRAM XRD as well as Campag’s own N3W freehubs.

  • Read more details on the Campagnolo Levante wheels

DT Swiss GR 1600 Spline Dyn front wheel

£299.99 (front wheel) | View offer

  • Dynamo hub in GR 1600 Spline or G 1800 Spline alloy front wheel
  • Efficient at speeds from 15km/h

If you’re into self-supported gravel adventures or night riding, a dynamo hub can power lights and devices. DT Swiss sells its 350 SP PL07 dynamo front hub laced into two of its alloy front wheels, as well as selling the hub alone. It says that the power input required from the rider is around 6 to 7 watts when drawing power and less than 1 watt when not in use. The dynamo will light your way at speeds as low as 15km/h.

DT claims a front wheel weight of 1,075g for the higher spec GR 1600 Spline Dyn. Both wheels are tubeless-ready and supplied pre-taped and with valves and lighting connectors.

  • Read more details on the DT Swiss GR 1600 Spline Dyn wheels
  • Buy now from Freewheel (£299.99)

DT Swiss GRC Spline

From £1,864.98 | View offer

  • 30mm or 50mm rim depth with hooked beads, built on two hub options
  • Available freehubs include Microspline, 650b wheel size offered

DT Swiss updated its GRC carbon gravel wheelsets in 2024, offering either a 30mm or a 50mm rim depth, with two hub options. The GRC Spline 30 is also available in 650b size, so there are six different wheelsets in total. DT says the shallower rims are designed for adventure and the deeper ones for gravel racing and both are aero optimised for 40mm gravel tyres.

Both rims have a 24mm internal width, but unlike the previous generation GRC wheels, DT has reverted to hooked beads, which it says are safer, easier to use and also more aero in its tests. Claimed weights start at 1,350g for the 30mm depth and 1,567g for the 50mm depth. There’s a Microspline freehub available for 1×12-speed Shimano GRX users.

  • Read more details on the DT Swiss GRC Spline wheels

Enve AG25 / AG28

£1,800 | View offer

  • 700c option with 25mm internal rim width or 650b with 28mm wide rim
  • Enve hubs with up to 100 points of engagement

The 25 and 28 in the names of Enve’s gravel wheels refer to the inner rim width, not the rim depth, with the 25 a 700c wheel recommended for 36mm to 50mm tyres and the 28 a 650b wheelset for 45mm to 57mm tyres. Both feature moulded spoke holes, which Enve says avoids the need to cut carbon fibres and so strengthens the rim and allows it to be lighter. The hookless rim is designed to reduce the risk of pinch flats and increase impact strength.

The shallow 21mm rim depth is chosen to increase compliance and vibration damping and Enve claims a weight of 1,460g for both wheelsets. The wheels are built on Enve Foundation Innerdrive hubs, which can be fitted with ratchets with 40, 60, 80 or 100 teeth, so you can choose very fast engagement.

  • Read more details on the Enve AG25 wheels
  • Buy now from Saddleback (£1,800)

Fulcrum Sharq

£2,289 | View offer

  • Designed for on/off-road use with 25mm width rims
  • Sinusoidal rim profile adds stability in crosswinds and gusty conditions

Billed by Fulcrum as an all-road wheelset, the Sharq’s 25mm width rim with mini-hooks is equally at home with gravel bike or road tyres. Its wavy rim, varying from 42mm to 47mm in depth, is claimed to improve stability and aerodynamics. Cup and cone ceramic bearings aid serviceability. and the 2-Way Fit rims can be set up tubeless without tape or run with tubes.

The Sharq wheels handle well in windy conditions, are less prone to gusts than many similar depth wheels and are responsive. We weighed our test wheels at 1,445g – not bad for a gravel wheelset, although a bit heavier than similarly priced road wheels.

  • Read our full Fulcrum Sharq wheelset review

Hunt 35 Carbon Gravel

£899 | View offer

  • Low weight and 25mm internal width
  • Brass nipples and J-bend spokes for easy trueing and replacement

Now renamed the Hunt 35 Carbon Gravel and with a reworked 25mm internal width hookless rim, the Hunt 35 Carbon Gravel wheelset also boasts a ratchet freehub with 36 points of engagement. There are still the same J-bend spokes and brass nipples, which should remain corrosion-free and trueable.

Hunt says that the wheels weigh 1,459g per set and are optimised for 40mm tyres, although you could run anything from 29mm to 64mm. We reckoned the predecessor to the current model, which we reviewed, offered great value for money. They coped with bashes, mud, rain and washing without complaint.

  • Read our full Hunt 35 Carbon Gravel wheelset review
  • Buy now from Hunt Wheels (£629.30)

Parcours FKT

£1,199 | View offer

  • Aero-optimised for 40mm tyres
  • Hookless 27mm internal width, 47mm deep rim

The Parcours FKT wheelset has a 27mm internal width, a hookless bead and 47mm depth and is aero-optimised around the Panaracer GravelKing X1 tyre in 40mm width. Parcours’ rim profile is designed to reduce turbulence caused by the tyre’s tread and it says it will offer aero gains with tyres from 35mm to 45mm wide.

The claimed wheelset weight is 1,500g and Parcours uses a more flexible resin at the rim’s edges to increase impact resistance. The hub is the same as Parcours uses on its road wheels and has a 44-tooth 6-pawl freehub.

  • Read more detail on the Parcours FKT gravel wheels
  • Buy now from Parcours (£1,199)

Zipp 303 XPLR SW

£1,600 | View offer

  • Aero and speed gains from very wide 32mm internal width hookless rims
  • Only deemed safe with matching tyres, which are prone to sidewall damage

The Zipp 303 XPLR SW wheelset is designed to provide an aero transition between the rim and wider gravel bike tyres. That means big internal width: 32mm, to be precise, dwarfing most gravel bike wheels, which stop at around 25mm. The 40mm external width is huge, wider than most MTB wheels, but the 1,496g wheelset weight is still relatively low.

Along with the 54mm depth, hookless beads and matching Goodyear tyres, Zipp claims this leads to a 2 watt saving at 32kmh over its most aero competitor, although at present there are only three gravel tyres that Zipp says are compatible. It claims that the real gains come from the very low tyre pressure that can be run and hence enhanced roll-over.

That’s something we experienced in our testing, when we found that the wheels allowed fast progress on hardpack gravel, although we felt the ride on tarmac was a little slow. Plus, although the flat sidewalls have aero benefits, this along with the low tyre pressure exposes them to damage from rocks, as we discovered.

  • Read our full Zipp 303 XPLR SW wheelset review

Gravel bike wheels: what to look for

Gravel wheels share many of their features with the best road bike wheels. We’ll not discuss tubeless-readiness and Centerlock disc rotor compatibility, which are both givens, but here’s what to look for when choosing.

Rim width

Wide gravel bike tyres call for wider rims to ensure good support and help avoid squirm. 25mm internal rim width is pretty much the starting point for gravel wheels, which according to ETRTO allows you to fit tyres between 28mm and 50mm in width. Some rims go considerably wider, although as we found with the 32mm internal rim Zipp 303 XPLR SW this isn’t without issues.

Many road rims are now approaching 25mm width too, so they’re an option for gravel use. Syncros, for example, recommends the 1,170g, £4,000 Capital SL 40 wheelset for gravel riding – if you dare.

Rim depth

Most rims designed for gravel riding are a little shallower than those designed for road use, with 35mm being typical, as against 40 to 50mm for all-rounder road bike wheels.

The rise of gravel racing and the increasing speeds at the front of gravel races mean that there are deeper profile gravel wheels available, such as the DT Swiss GRC 50mm, above, and the Hunt 40 Limitless Gravel Aero. But while shallower section wheels are likely to be more compliant over rough ground, brands need to be careful to ensure that deeper section gravel wheels aren’t too rigid for a comfortable ride.

Rim bead shape

For road wheels, the discussion of the merits of rims with hookless beads continues; the same is true to some extent with gravel wheels. Hooked versus hookless may be less of an issue for gravel wheels though, as the tyre is wider and run at significantly lower pressure, more akin to MTB tyres, where hookless has been a feature for some time.

This can lead to problems with burping rather than the tyre coming off the rim completely though.

Many brands offer hookless gravel bike rims, but others such as Campagnolo continue to use a hooked rim profile. DT Swiss has reverted from hookless to hooked beads, as it believes that hooked rims are intrinsically safer.

Wheel size

Gravel bikes are increasingly designed for 700c wheels and specced with them, with the smaller 650b wheel size going somewhat out of favour. That’s due in no small measure to the increased 700c tyre clearance offered by modern gravel bikes, with 50mm now typical.

You may be able to fit 650b wheels with wider gravel tyres to your bike, but the choice of newer wheelsets is now fairly limited.

Aerodynamics

As mentioned above, gravel race speeds have increased to the point where aerodynamics are significant, so gravel bike wheels are now often aero tested as part of the design process. Often that’s at lower wind speeds than road bike wheels, with 35km/h being typical, as against 45km/h or more for road wheels.

The lower test speeds result in fewer watts in claimed savings, but they’re still potentially significant if you plan to race on gravel or just want a wheelset that feels faster once you hit tarmacked roads.

The wider profile of gravel tyres and lugged tread make aerodynamics more tricky too, so unless you run the same tyre in the same width as was tested and for which the wheel profile was designed, you may not achieve the claimed aero benefits.

Maintenance

The rougher, dirtier environment off-road means that gravel wheels are more likely to need maintenance than road bike wheels, although this is no more of an issue than with MTB wheels.

Often, manufacturers will prefer spokes with external nipples for gravel wheels and brass may be chosen over alloy, despite the slight increase in weight, as brass nipples are less prone to freeze.

Some wheel makers may choose J-bend spokes over straight-pull, as they can be easier to source if you break one. As a bonus, they may increase a wheel’s compliance.

Hubs and freehubs

Although cartridge bearings may be chosen, there are a fair few wheelsets in our selection above with cup and cone bearings, which can be serviced more easily. Brands typically ensure good weatherproofing in gravel wheel hubs, often with multiple seals.

Freehubs may be designed with a larger number of points of engagement, to ensure quick pick-up when riding over tricky ground. Ratchet freehubs are often specced for their larger contact area than that offered by pawl freehubs and their perceived ability to handle higher loads.
